articles.title: The Top 7 Growth Stocks to Buy in March 2024
summarizedBulletPoints: - **Spotify (SPOT)** reports its first GAAP profit for a full fiscal year, marking a significant transformation with $743 million in free cash flow and a 15.21% YOY revenue increase to $14.6 billion.
- Monthly active users (MAUs) hit a record high last year, with expectations to exceed 1 billion in the upcoming years.
- Strategic focus on gross margin expansion and double-digit growth in premium subscriptions across various markets underline Spotify's strong growth trajectory.
- Spotify possesses a healthy liquidity position, with approximately $4.38 billion in cash and marketable securities, positioning it as a leading growth stock to buy.
articles.desc: In the current bullish phase, top growth stocks to buy are imperative for investors aiming for durable long-term growth and market leadership.

"https:\/\/investorplace.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/10\/growthstocks_1600_02.jpg",        "height": 900,        "width": 1600    },    "articleBody": "Baidu (BIDU):\u00a0Baidu's Q4 earnings beat and its ambitious revenue target for 2024, fueled by AI innovations, signals robust expansion ahead Netflix\u00a0(NFLX):\u00a0With a strategic shift to include an ad-supported tier and a subscriber base of over 260 million, Netflix's strong Q4 showing underpins its enduring dominance in streaming BYD (BYDDF):\u00a0Outperforming Tesla in the global EV market, BYD's expansion with new factories and a diverse, affordable EV lineup underscores its aggressive growth trajectory Continue reading the list of the Top Growth Stocks to Buy! Growth stocks to buy can potentially redefine your portfolio’s performance. Amid a bullish market, savvy investors are pursuing businesses with an unyielding trajectory of top-and-bottom-line expansion. Often at the forefront of innovation, such companies tend to attract those seeking robust long-term capital appreciation. Moreover, the current bullish phase underscores the potential of these investments. Growth stocks are likely to surge at a robust pace in this buoyant market, and adding them to your investment strategy could be your ticket to sustained financial triumph. With that said, here are seven top growth stocks to buy to add to your portfolios for healthy long-term gains. Top Growth Stocks to Buy: Baidu (BIDU) Source: monticello \/ Shutterstock.comBaidu’s (NASDAQ:BIDU) foray into artificial intelligence (AI), particularly with its Ernie Bot, has elevated its status in the AI realm but also turbocharged its financial performance. Its fourth-quarter (Q4) report is a testament to this notion, with it delivering a comfortable $50 million beat on its top-line posting of $4.92 billion. This uptick, fueled by its advertising sector and innovative AI applications, underscores the company's adeptness at harnessing AI’s potential to drive growth. Moreover, it beat the $3.08 non-GAAP EPADS forecast by 58 cents, highlighting its strategic prowess in navigating the economic downturn in China with resilience. Looking ahead, Baidu’s CFO Rong Luo sets an ambitious tone for 2024, targeting $20.34 billion in revenue, representing a stellar 8.76% year-over-year (YOY) increase. This projection reflects confidence in the company's operational efficiencies and underscores the delicate balance the company aims to strike between its AI investments and overall growth. Moreover, as Baidu navigates this path, its efforts to blend AI innovation with financial prudence could set a benchmark for tech companies globally. Netflix (NFLX) Source: izzuanroslan \/ Shutterstock.comNetflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) remains a dominant player in the global streaming landscape and continues to be unassailable, a position that is expected to continue in the foreseeable future. It has consistently outperformed earnings estimates in three out of the last four quarters. The strategic pivot to restructure management and introducing an ad-supported membership tier has started bearing fruit, ushering in a new era of advertising sales growth. With a subscriber base exceeding 260 million worldwide, the new ad tier could be a potential game-changer for Netflix’s revenue model. The firm's Q4 report card reveals a strong 13% year-over-year increase in total revenue and subscriber count, along with optimistic, forward-looking guidance.  The projection of $9.24 billion in revenue for the first quarter (Q1) of the fiscal year 2024, aiming for a 13% YOY growth and an anticipated operating margin expansion of 520 basis points, paints a promising picture ahead for the streaming giant. BYD (BYDDF) Source: J. Lekavicius \/ Shutterstock.comBYD (OTCMKTS:BYDDF) has made significant strides in the electric vehicle (EV) market over the past few years, overtaking Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) as a top global EV player last year. This achievement is rooted in BYD’s diverse and affordable product lineup, growing exports, and increasing top-line as the company boosts production efficiencies. Furthermore, it is looking to open up a new factory in Hungary and plans for another in Mexico as it aggressively expands its global footprint. Additionally, the EV juggernaut offers five models across Europe and has introduced eight low-cost cars in the last two years. On top of that, BYD’s position as the world’s second-largest battery maker narrows the gap further with Tesla. This dual capability highlights BYD’s significant long-term potential for expansion and its ambition to lead the EV market in the coming years. Microsoft (MSFT) Source: The Art of Pics \/ Shutterstock.comMicrosoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) efficiently navigated the AI surge, fortifying its standing through early investments in OpenAI before AI’s ascent to mainstream prominence. Recent endeavors to broaden its AI investment portfolio complement its foresight, underscoring its commitment to an AI-powered future. Moreover, another major growth segment for the company is Microsoft Cloud, which is emerging as a key growth catalyst. This segment alone reported a remarkable 24% YOY revenue increase in the second quarter (Q2), accounting for more than 50% of Microsoft’s total revenues. Overall, it posted a vigorous 18% YOY growth in sales and an even more striking 33% jump in net income. Looking ahead, Microsoft sets ambitious goals, aiming for $500 billion in revenue by 2030. Pivotal to its vision is its investment in cloud infrastructure, including developing proprietary AI GPU chips while reducing dependence on external entities. Mastercard (MA) Source: David Cardinez \/ Shutterstock.comMastercard (NYSE:MA) is a true titan in the fintech space, leveraging its position as a credit and debit card giant to consistently deliver high-profit margins. Moreover, it underscores a broader shift towards electronic payments, a trend promising continued expansion. To put things in perspective, it processed over $9 trillion in payment volume last year. Additionally, the firm is in a position for further penetration on a global scale, with cash transactions still prevalent in developing markets. Its financial metrics reveal a dynamic picture, with Mastercard reporting a 13% YOY increase in Q4 revenue and an 11% climb in net income. Such growth is propelled by double-digit expansions in key business metrics including gross dollar volume, cross-border volume, and switched transactions. Beyond its financials, Mastercard’s shareholder value proposition remains equally impressive. Mastercard has proven to be a reliable steward of shareholder wealth with a forward dividend yield of 0.56% and a 17.02% five-year growth rate in payouts. Lennar (LEN) Source: ARMMY PICCA\/ShutterStock.comLennar (NYSE:LEN) is the second-largest homebuilding entity in the U.S., occupying a leadership position amid a national housing shortage. This shortage has provided Lennar with a golden opportunity to expand its market presence, evidenced by a 13% increase in net new orders, totaling 69,111 last year. Moreover, its financial health remains excellent, with Q4 results reflecting its strategic positioning, showcasing an 8% YOY revenue increase to $11 billion and a 6% bump in EPS to $4.62. Despite the challenges posed by higher mortgage rates, home deliveries increased by 19% to 23,795 with a backlog of 14,892 homes at the end of Q4. Additionally, the firm's investor appeal is further highlighted by its impressive 1.24% yield, an attractive forward P\/E ratio of just 11.2 times, and a substantial cash reserve exceeding $6 billion. Hence, Lennar can navigate the housing market’s complexities with considerable aplomb, promising sustainable growth and long-term shareholder value creation. Spotify (SPOT) Source: Diego Thomazini \/ Shutterstock.comSpotify (NYSE:SPOT) is poised for a transformative leap, posting its first GAAP profit for a full fiscal year, a milestone that will catapult it to unprecedented heights. Despite not turning a profit last year, Spotify showcases formidable operational strength, marking a 15.21% YOY revenue surge to $14.6 billion while achieving a record $743 million in free cash flow (FCF). Moreover, its monthly active users (MAUs) peaked last year and are projected to exceed 1 billion in the forthcoming years. Its strategic focus on gross margin expansion and the double-digit growth of premium subscriptions across various markets underscore its powerful growth trajectory. Coupled with a healthy liquidity position, boasting approximately $4.38 billion in cash and marketable securities, Spotify has positioned itself as a leading growth stock to buy On the date of publication, Muslim Farooque did not have (either directly or indirectly) any positions in the securities mentioned in this article. The opinions expressed in this article are those of the writer, subject to the InvestorPlace.com Publishing Guidelines Muslim Farooque is a keen investor and an optimist at heart. story">							<p><a class="auto-linked-term" href="https://investorplace.com/stock-types/growth-stocks/">Growth stocks</a> to buy can potentially redefine your portfolio’s performance. Amid a bullish market, savvy investors are pursuing businesses with an unyielding trajectory of top-and-bottom-line expansion. Often at the forefront of innovation, such companies tend to attract those seeking robust long-term capital appreciation. </p><p>Moreover, the current bullish phase underscores the potential of these investments. Growth stocks are likely to surge at a robust pace in this buoyant market, and adding them to your investment strategy could be your ticket to sustained financial triumph. With that said, here are seven top growth stocks to buy to add to your portfolios for healthy long-term gains.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Top Growth Stocks to Buy: Baidu (BIDU)</h2><div id="2332474" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-300x169.png" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Laptop computer displaying logo of Baidu (BIDU), a Chinese multinational technology company specializing in Internet-related services and products" class="alignright wp-image-2332474" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-300x169.png 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-1024x576.png 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-768x432.png 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-1536x864.png 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-200x113.png 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-400x225.png 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-116x65.png 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-100x56.png 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-89x50.png 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1-78x44.png 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/bidu1600-2-1.png 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: monticello / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Baidu’s</strong> (NASDAQ:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/bidu-stock-quote/"><strong><u>BIDU</u></strong></a>) foray into artificial intelligence (<a class="ipm-ticker-link" href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/ai-stock-quote/"><strong>AI</strong></a>), particularly with its Ernie Bot, has elevated its status in the AI realm but also turbocharged its financial performance. Its fourth-quarter (Q4) report is a testament to this notion, with it delivering a comfortable $50 million beat on its top-line posting of $4.92 billion. This uptick, fueled by its advertising sector and innovative AI applications, underscores the company’s adeptness at harnessing AI’s potential to drive growth. Moreover, it beat the <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/news/4072815-baidu-non-gaap-epads-of-308-beats-by-058-revenue-of-492b-beats-by-50m" rel="nofollow">$3.08 non-GAAP EPADS</a> forecast by 58 cents, highlighting its strategic prowess in navigating the economic downturn in China with resilience.</p><p>Looking ahead, Baidu’s CFO Rong Luo sets an ambitious tone for 2024, targeting $20.34 billion in revenue, representing a stellar 8.76% year-over-year (YOY) increase. This projection reflects confidence in the company’s operational efficiencies and underscores the delicate balance the company aims to strike between its AI investments and overall growth. Moreover, as Baidu navigates this path, its efforts to blend AI innovation with financial prudence could set a benchmark for tech companies globally.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Netflix (NFLX)</h2><div id="2389368" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-300x169.png" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Netflix (NFLX) logo displayed on smartphone on top of pile of money." class="alignright wp-image-2389368" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-300x169.png 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-1024x576.png 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-768x432.png 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-1536x864.png 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-200x113.png 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-400x225.png 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-116x65.png 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-100x56.png 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-89x50.png 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1-78x44.png 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/nflx1600-1.png 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: izzuanroslan / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Netflix </strong>(NASDAQ:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/nflx-stock-quote/"><strong><u>NFLX</u></strong></a>) remains a dominant player in the global streaming landscape and continues to be unassailable, a position that is expected to continue in the foreseeable future. It has consistently outperformed earnings estimates in three out of the last four quarters. The strategic pivot to restructure management and introducing an ad-supported membership tier has started bearing fruit, ushering in a new era of advertising sales growth. With a subscriber base <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/news/4057560-netflix-gains-4-with-best-subscriber-growth-since-pandemic-boost-revenue-beat" rel="nofollow">exceeding 260 million worldwide</a>, the new ad tier could be a potential game-changer for Netflix’s revenue model.</p><p>The firm’s Q4 report card reveals a strong 13% year-over-year increase in total revenue and subscriber count, along with optimistic, forward-looking guidance.  The projection of <a href="https://investorplace.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=2733137&action=edit">$9.24 billion in revenue</a> for the first quarter (Q1) of the fiscal year 2024, aiming for a 13% YOY growth and an anticipated operating margin expansion of 520 basis points, paints a promising picture ahead for the streaming giant.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">BYD (BYDDF)</h2><div id="1709494" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-300x169.jpg" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="A close-up view of the power supply plugged into a vehicle from BYD Company (BYDDY)." class="alignright wp-image-1709494" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-300x169.jpg 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-1024x576.jpg 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-768x432.jpg 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-1536x864.jpg 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-200x113.jpg 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-400x225.jpg 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-116x65.jpg 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-100x56.jpg 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-89x50.jpg 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1-78x44.jpg 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/byddf-stock-1.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: J. Lekavicius / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>BYD</strong> (OTCMKTS:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/byddf-stock-quote/"><strong><u>BYDDF</u></strong></a>) has made significant strides in the electric vehicle (EV) market over the past few years, overtaking <strong>Tesla</strong> (NASDAQ:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/tsla-stock-quote/"><strong><u>TSLA</u></strong></a>) as a top global EV player last year. This achievement is rooted in BYD’s diverse and affordable product lineup, growing exports, and increasing top-line as the company boosts production efficiencies.</p><p>Furthermore, it is looking to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/22/business/byd-china-hungary.html#:~:text=Last%20year%2C%20it%20sold%201.86,BYD%20said%20in%20a%20statement." rel="nofollow">open up a new factory in Hungary</a> and plans for another in Mexico as it aggressively expands its global footprint. Additionally, the EV juggernaut offers five models across Europe and has introduced eight low-cost cars in the last two years. On top of that, BYD’s position as the world’s <a href="https://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3223117/supercharged-byd-overtakes-lg-worlds-no-2-ev-battery-supplier-electrification-drive-quickens" rel="nofollow">second-largest battery maker</a> narrows the gap further with Tesla. This dual capability highlights BYD’s significant long-term potential for expansion and its ambition to lead the EV market in the coming years.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Microsoft (MSFT)</h2><div id="2459325" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-300x169.png" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Microsoft logo close up. Microsoft (MSFT) Flagship Store Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, NYC." class="alignright wp-image-2459325" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-300x169.png 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-1024x576.png 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-768x432.png 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-1536x864.png 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-200x113.png 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-400x225.png 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-116x65.png 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-100x56.png 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-89x50.png 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1-78x44.png 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/msft1600-1.png 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: The Art of Pics / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Microsoft</strong> (NASDAQ:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/msft-stock-quote/"><strong><u>MSFT</u></strong></a>) efficiently navigated the AI surge, fortifying its standing through early investments in OpenAI before AI’s ascent to mainstream prominence. Recent endeavors to broaden its AI investment portfolio complement its foresight, underscoring its commitment to an AI-powered future.</p><p>Moreover, another major growth segment for the company is Microsoft Cloud, which is emerging as a key growth catalyst. This segment alone reported <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/investor/earnings/fy-2024-q2/press-release-webcast" rel="nofollow">a remarkable 24% YOY </a>revenue increase in the second quarter (Q2), accounting for more than 50% of Microsoft’s total revenues. Overall, it posted a vigorous 18% YOY growth in sales and an even more striking 33% jump in net income.</p><p>Looking ahead, Microsoft sets ambitious goals, aiming for $500 billion in revenue by 2030. Pivotal to its vision is its investment in cloud infrastructure, including developing proprietary AI GPU chips while reducing dependence on external entities.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Mastercard (MA)</h2><div id="1671916" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-300x169.jpg" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Close up of a pile of mastercard credit load debit bank cards." class="alignright wp-image-1671916" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-300x169.jpg 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-1024x576.jpg 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-768x432.jpg 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-1536x864.jpg 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-200x113.jpg 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-400x225.jpg 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-116x65.jpg 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-100x56.jpg 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-89x50.jpg 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600-78x44.jpg 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/mastercard-ma-1600.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: David Cardinez / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Mastercard</strong> (NYSE:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/ma-stock-quote/"><strong><u>MA</u></strong></a>) is a true titan in the fintech space, leveraging its position as a credit and debit card giant to consistently deliver high-profit margins. Moreover, it underscores a broader shift towards electronic payments, a trend promising continued expansion. To put things in perspective, it processed<a href="https://fortune.com/2024/03/06/mastercard-ai-detect-fraud/#:~:text=This%20doesn't%20strike%20me,of%20transactions%20globally%20last%20year." rel="nofollow"> over $9 trillion in payment volume </a>last year. Additionally, the firm is in a position for further penetration on a global scale, with cash transactions still prevalent in developing markets.</p><p>Its financial metrics reveal a dynamic picture, with Mastercard reporting a 13% YOY increase in Q4 revenue and an 11% climb in net income. Such growth is propelled by double-digit expansions in key business metrics including gross dollar volume, cross-border volume, and switched transactions. Beyond its financials, Mastercard’s shareholder value proposition remains equally impressive. Mastercard has proven to be a reliable steward of shareholder wealth with a <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/symbol/MA/dividends/scorecard" rel="nofollow">forward dividend yield of 0.56%</a> and a 17.02% five-year growth rate in payouts.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Lennar (LEN)</h2><div id="2141600" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-300x169.png" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="A photo of a person in a neon green vest holding blueprints and standing behind a white table covered with supplies like pencils, a computer, a ruler and two wooden house shapes. Homebuilder Stocks" class="alignright wp-image-2141600" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-300x169.png 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-1024x576.png 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-768x432.png 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-1536x864.png 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-200x113.png 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-400x225.png 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-116x65.png 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-100x56.png 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-89x50.png 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600-78x44.png 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/homebuilder_construction_1600.png 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: ARMMY PICCA/ShutterStock.com</div></div><p><strong>Lennar</strong> (NYSE:<a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/len-stock-quote/"><strong><u>LEN</u></strong></a>) is the second-largest homebuilding entity in the U.S., occupying a leadership position amid a national housing shortage. This shortage has provided Lennar with a golden opportunity to expand its market presence, evidenced by a 13% increase in net new orders, totaling 69,111 last year.</p><p>Moreover, its financial health remains excellent, with Q4 results reflecting its strategic positioning, <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/news/4046616-lennar-non-gaap-eps-of-5_17-beats-0_57-revenue-of-10_97b-beats-680m" rel="nofollow">showcasing an 8% YOY</a> revenue increase to $11 billion and a 6% bump in EPS to $4.62. Despite the challenges posed by higher mortgage rates, home deliveries increased by 19% to 23,795 with a backlog of 14,892 homes at the end of Q4.</p><p>Additionally, the firm’s investor appeal is further highlighted by its impressive 1.24% yield, an attractive forward P/E ratio <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/symbol/LEN/valuation/metrics" rel="nofollow">of just 11.2 times</a>, and a substantial cash reserve exceeding $6 billion. Hence, Lennar can navigate the housing market’s complexities with considerable aplomb, promising sustainable growth and long-term shareholder value creation.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Spotify (SPOT)</h2><div id="2206325" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" that will catapult it to unprecedented heights. Despite not turning a profit last year, Spotify showcases formidable operational strength, marking a <a href="https://seekingalpha.com/symbol/SPOT/income-statement" rel="nofollow">15.21% YOY revenue surge</a> to $14.6 billion while achieving a record $743 million in free cash flow (<a class="ipm-ticker-link" href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/fcf-stock-quote/"><strong>FCF</strong></a>).</p><p>Moreover, its monthly active users (MAUs) peaked last year and are projected to exceed 1 billion in the forthcoming years. Its strategic focus on gross margin expansion and the double-digit growth of premium subscriptions across various markets underscore its powerful growth trajectory. articles.title: Is Spotify Technology (SPOT) Stock Outpacing Its Business Services Peers This Year?
summarizedBulletPoints: - The article discusses SPOT (Spotify Technology) and its performance relative to the Business Services sector.
- Spotify is a member of the Business Services group, which includes 315 companies, ranking #7 in the Zacks Sector Rank.
- Spotify currently has a Zacks Rank of #1 (Strong Buy), indicating potential outperformance in the market.
- The company's year-to-date earnings estimates have increased by 61% in the last quarter, hinting at a positive earnings outlook.
- So far this year, Spotify's stock has returned 43.9%, outperforming the Business Services sector's average gain of 10.2%.
- Another company mentioned in comparison is Trane Technologies (TT), which has a year-to-date return of 17.9% and a current Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).
- Both Spotify and Trane Technologies are part of the Technology Services industry, with Spotify outperforming the industry average year-to-date return of 18.4%.
- The article suggests keeping an eye on both Spotify and Trane Technologies for those interested in Business Services stocks.
articles.desc:
The Business Services group has plenty of great stocks, but investors should always be looking for companies that are outperforming their peers. Is Spotify (SPOT) one of those stocks right now? A quick glance at the company's year-to-date performance in comparison to the rest of the Business Services sector should help us answer this question.

Spotify is a member of our Business Services group, which includes 315 different companies and currently sits at #7 in the Zacks Sector Rank. The Zacks Sector Rank includes 16 different groups and is listed in order from best to worst in terms of the average Zacks Rank of the individual companies within each of these sectors.

The Zacks Rank is a successful stock-picking model that emphasizes earnings estimates and estimate revisions. The system highlights a number of different stocks that could be poised to outperform the broader market over the next one to three months. Spotify is currently sporting a Zacks Rank of #1 (Strong Buy).

The Zacks Consensus Estimate for SPOT's full-year earnings has moved 61% higher within the past quarter. This means that analyst sentiment is stronger and the stock's earnings outlook is improving.

Based on the most recent data, SPOT has returned 43.9% so far this year. At the same time, Business Services stocks have gained an average of 10.2%. This means that Spotify is outperforming the sector as a whole this year.

Another stock in the Business Services sector, Trane Technologies (TT), has outperformed the sector so far this year. The stock's year-to-date return is 17.9%.

In Trane Technologies' case, the consensus EPS estimate for the current year increased 1.1% over the past three months. The stock currently has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).

To break things down more, Spotify belongs to the Technology Services industry, a group that includes 174 individual companies and currently sits at #83 in the Zacks Industry Rank. On average, stocks in this group have gained 18.4% this year, meaning that SPOT is performing better in terms of year-to-date returns. Trane Technologies is also part of the same industry.

Story continues

Investors with an interest in Business Services stocks should continue to track Spotify and Trane Technologies. These stocks will be looking to continue their solid performance.

articles.title: Spotify to increase prices in France over new tax
summarizedBulletPoints: - Spotify, which trades under the SPOT stock symbol, announced it will be increasing its subscription prices in France.
- The price hike is in response to a new 1.2% tax imposed by the French government on streaming services' revenues to support music creation.
- Spotify criticized the tax, arguing that it would not aid in music creation and would instead burden French users with the highest subscription fees in the European Union.
- The exact amount of the price increase will be disclosed at a later date.
- The Swedish streaming giant contends that the tax is misguided and will simply introduce an additional intermediary, the CNM (France's National Music Centre), at the expense of listeners.
- France's government anticipates that the tax will generate approximately 15 million euros ($16.35 million) this year, aimed at supporting the music industry through the CNM.
- Jean-Philippe Thiellay, head of the CNM, defended the tax, stating it is intended to finance creation and diversity in the music sector, not to fund the CNM itself.
articles.desc:
PARIS (Reuters) - Swedish streaming service Spotify on Thursday said it would increase its prices in France due to a new tax, which it argued would fail to accomplish its intended goal.

The government last year decided, starting form this year, to slap a 1.2% tax on the revenue streaming companies make in France to help finance music creation.

"While Spotify worked very hard to encourage the government to avoid adding this tax, unfortunately they decided to move forward," the Swedish group said in a statement.

"To put it bluntly, all French users will see their subscription plan fee go up. French users will now pay the highest subscriptions across the European Union."

It said it would announce the extent of the price increase at a later stage.

In its statement, Spotify said the tax was misguided and would not help music creation.

"It will simply come at the expense of listeners and create an additional middleman: the CNM," it said, referring to France's National Music Centre.

The tax, which the government hopes will raise about 15 million euros ($16.35 million) this year, will contribute to CNM's support for the music industry, including helping emerging artists and French artists trying to break through abroad, the government has said.

The head of the CNM, Jean-Philippe Thiellay, has rejected Spotify's criticism.

The tax "will not finance the CNM, whose operations are ensured by the state, but it will finance creation and diversity," he told France Musique radio in an interview last year. "100% of this tax will be re-injected into the sector."

($1 = 0.9173 euros)

(Writing by Ingrid Melander; Editing by Tomasz Janowski)
articles.htmlContent:
Reuters

Spotify to increase prices in France over new tax

Reuters
March 7, 2024 at 2:51 AM·1 min read

PARIS (Reuters) - Swedish streaming service Spotify on Thursday said it would increase its prices in France due to a new tax, which it argued would fail to accomplish its intended goal.

The government last year decided, starting form this year, to slap a 1.2% tax on the revenue streaming companies make in France to help finance music creation.

"While Spotify worked very hard to encourage the government to avoid adding this tax, unfortunately they decided to move forward," the Swedish group said in a statement.

"To put it bluntly, all French users will see their subscription plan fee go up. French users will now pay the highest subscriptions across the European Union."

It said it would announce the extent of the price increase at a later stage.

In its statement, Spotify said the tax was misguided and would not help music creation.

"It will simply come at the expense of listeners and create an additional middleman: the CNM," it said, referring to France's National Music Centre.

The tax, which the government hopes will raise about 15 million euros ($16.35 million) this year, will contribute to CNM's support for the music industry, including helping emerging artists and French artists trying to break through abroad, the government has said.

The head of the CNM, Jean-Philippe Thiellay, has rejected Spotify's criticism.

The tax "will not finance the CNM, whose operations are ensured by the state, but it will finance creation and diversity," he told France Musique radio in an interview last year. "100% of this tax will be re-injected into the sector."

($1 = 0.9173 euros)

(Writing by Ingrid Melander; Editing by Tomasz Janowski)

articles.title: Global pop star says she cant afford to take a week off due to how little she gets paid from streaming
summarizedBulletPoints: - Sevdaliza, an Iranian-Dutch artist with over 1 million monthly listeners on Spotify, discusses the financial challenges faced by independent artists in the music industry.

- Despite her success and fanbase built over 12 years without major labels, Sevdaliza highlights that the revenue from one million streams, approximately $2,500, is insufficient when considering taxes, management, and production costs.

- The article references James Blake's critique of the streaming system, emphasizing that streaming services, record labels, TikTok, and the costs of touring do not adequately support artists financially.

- Spotify, mentioned explicitly, reported record growth with an addition of 31 million premium subscribers last year, but this growth contrasts with the slim payouts artists receive from streaming services.
- Artists like Zo Keating and Nadine Shah share their perspectives on the minimal income from streaming, which hardly covers basic expenses like groceries or rent.

- Lauren Jauregui, formerly of Fifth Harmony, points out the discrepancy between apparent success on social media and the reality of financial struggles due to the exploitative nature of the music industry.
- Sevdaliza considers creating a music artist union to advocate for musicians' rights, expressing the sacrifices made for her career at the expense of her health and being a present mother.

- The article concludes with Sevdaliza's reflection on the paradox of loving music while not being compensated fairly for her art, questioning the sustainability of the current business model for artists.
articles.desc:
Sevdaliza might have more than 1 million monthly listeners on Spotify, but that doesnt mean much when it comes to making ends meet. The Iranian-Dutch artist has made waves in the electronic-pop sphere with her experimental music, but that seemingly amounts to a drop in the bucket when it comes to her bank account.

I have been an independent artist for 12 years releasing music, Ive built everything including a fanbase without majors, and I still cant afford to take a week off, tweeted Sevdaliza, adding that on average, one million streams amounts to an artist being paid $2,500. Deduct taxes, management and cost of product. How are we expected to ever make music sustainable? wondered the artist who once collaborated with Grimes.

Sevdaliza's message was a response to a viral post from another artist, James Blake, regarding the streaming system.

If we want quality music somebody is gonna have to pay for it, he said, explaining the waning options for making money. Streaming services dont pay properly, labels want a bigger cut than ever and just sit and wait for you to go viral, TikTok doesnt pay properly, and touring is getting prohibitively expensive for most artists.

Indeed, streaming has overtaken the music industrySpotify reported record growth, adding 31 million premium subscribers last year. Much like how royalties checks for actors are slimmer for a Netflix show than a cable one, payouts from these music streaming services dont have the same impact that physical albums once did. Artist Zo Keating shared with Business Insider in 2020 that for her, a single stream from Apple Music accounted for $0.012; on Spotify, shed receive just $0.003 after distributor fees.

No one said making it big was easy, but it seems all the more impossible these days for independent artists to catch a break. The streaming era has made the process all the more grueling as independent artists struggle to make a living in an especially volatile economy.

Story continues

If we got paid a meaningful income from streaming, that could be a weekly grocery shop; it could contribute to your rent or your mortgage when you need it the most, artist Nadine Shah told the New York Times. Thats why I felt compelled to talk about it. I saw so many artists struggling. Of course, the creator economy can make it even more difficult to become a star amongst all the short-form competition out there.

Responding to James Blakes post, Lauren Jauregui (who rose to fame as a member of Fifth Harmony) says that amongst her artist friends, everyone feels like we have no right to get paid for our work. Claiming that music is the only industry thats like this, Jauregui adds that people conflate popularity or follower count with success [so] they cant conceptualize how extractive and abusive these systems are to us. In response, Sevdaliza said she was looking to combat the exploitation by potentially starting a music artist union, that solely advocates for the rights of musicians.

As it stands, being an artist isnt tenable, as Sevdaliza describes it. I have to sacrifice my health and cant be a present mother, because of our business model, the artist says. The thing is, if you want to make it in music, you cant stop. I love music so much, and I dont ever want to give up but we dont get paid for our art. It doesnt make any sense.

This story was originally featured on Fortune.com

I have been an independent artist for 12 years releasing music, Ive built everything including a fanbase without majors, and I still cant afford to take a week off, tweeted Sevdaliza, adding that on average, one million streams amounts to an artist being paid $2,500. Deduct taxes, management and cost of product. How are we expected to ever make music sustainable? wondered the artist who once collaborated with Grimes.

Sevdaliza's message was a response to a viral post from another artist, James Blake, regarding the streaming system.

If we want quality music somebody is gonna have to pay for it, he said, explaining the waning options for making money. Streaming services dont pay properly, labels want a bigger cut than ever and just sit and wait for you to go viral, TikTok doesnt pay properly, and touring is getting prohibitively expensive for most artists.

Indeed, streaming has overtaken the music industrySpotify reported record growth, adding 31 million premium subscribers last year. Much like how royalties checks for actors are slimmer for a Netflix show than a cable one, payouts from these music streaming services dont have the same impact that physical albums once did. Artist Zo Keating shared with Business Insider in 2020 that for her, a single stream from Apple Music accounted for $0.012; on Spotify, shed receive just $0.003 after distributor fees.

No one said making it big was easy, but it seems all the more impossible these days for independent artists to catch a break. The streaming era has made the process all the more grueling as independent artists struggle to make a living in an especially volatile economy.

If we got paid a meaningful income from streaming, that could be a weekly grocery shop; it could contribute to your rent or your mortgage when you need it the most, artist Nadine Shah told the New York Times. Thats why I felt compelled to talk about it. I saw so many artists struggling. Of course, the creator economy can make it even more difficult to become a star amongst all the short-form competition out there.

Responding to James Blakes post, Lauren Jauregui (who rose to fame as a member of Fifth Harmony) says that amongst her artist friends, everyone feels like we have no right to get paid for our work. Claiming that music is the only industry thats like this, Jauregui adds that people conflate popularity or follower count with success [so] they cant conceptualize how extractive and abusive these systems are to us. In response, Sevdaliza said she was looking to combat the exploitation by potentially starting a music artist union, that solely advocates for the rights of musicians.

As it stands, being an artist isnt tenable, as Sevdaliza describes it. I have to sacrifice my health and cant be a present mother, because of our business model, the artist says. The thing is, if you want to make it in music, you cant stop. I love music so much, and I dont ever want to give up but we dont get paid for our art. It doesnt make any sense.

This story was originally featured on Fortune.com

articles.title: Have $10,000? 3 Elite Growth Stocks to Buy Right Now
summarizedBulletPoints: - **Spotify (SPOT)** is highlighted as a global music streaming giant expected to deliver significant returns over the next decade, potentially moving closer to achieving GAAP profitability for a full fiscal year.
- In FY23, Spotify reported a 13% YOY increase in revenue to $13.24 billion, with a record FCF of $674 million. They achieved a surprise profit of $0.33 per share in Q3 2023.

- Spotify's Monthly Active Users (MAU) reached 602 million, with projections to surpass 1 billion in the coming years. The company has seen double-digit growth in premium subscriptions across all regions, contributing to gross margin expansion.

- The company's liquidity remains solid, with approximately $4.3 billion in cash and marketable securities. With operating losses expected to shrink over the next quarters, Spotify is considered one of the elite growth stocks to buy in March.
articles.desc: Amazon, Netflix and Spotify are the 3 elite growth stocks to buy right now to add some extra juice to your portfolio.

"2024-03-06T14:43:44-05:00",    "image": {        "@type": "ImageObject",        "url": "https:\/\/investorplace.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/01\/growthstocks1600-1.png",        "height": 900,        "width": 1600    },    "articleBody": "These elite growth stocks to buy will continue to outperform the market.\u00a0 Amazon (AMZN): When it's all said and done, AMZN stock will hold a large market share of the generative AI market.\u00a0 Netflix (NFLX): Operating margin is expected to expand by 520 bps in Q1 FY24 for the streamer.\u00a0 Spotify (SPOT): The streaming music company anticipates 16 million net new MAUs in the first quarter of 2024. Finding elite growth stocks to buy to outperform the market is a worthy endeavor. These companies can be characterized by their consistent expansion of revenue, earnings and market capitalization.  Elite growth stocks go hand in hand with innovative industries like artificial intelligence. Investors who are seeking to build portfolios with a focus on long-term capital appreciation gravitate towards these stocks, recognizing their potential to outperform their competitors. If you're patient with a long-term mindset, rest assured that you'll be sitting comfortably with these three elite companies.  Now, let's discuss the three best elite growth stocks to buy right now! Amazon (AMZN) Source: Sundry Photography \/ Shutterstock.comAmazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) hit a key inflection point in 2023 making it primed for more upside. It continues to lead from the front in the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution and is set to become the world's largest company by revenue.  Generative AI will continue to be one of the leading investment ideas for the foreseeable future. Bloomberg Intelligence estimates the generative AI market to become a $1.3 trillion industry by 2032, growing at a mindblowing 42% compounded annual growth rate (CAGR). Amazon stands to get a big piece of the pie, through their comprehensive suite of generative AI products. This includes Amazon Bedrock, Amazon Q, Code Whisperer and AWS Tranium.  In FY23, Amazon's revenue increased 12% year-over-year (YOY) to $574.8 billion. Operating income skyrocketed to $36.9 billion, compared with $12.2 billion in 2022. However, what got Wall Street excited is Amazon's record free cash flow (FCF) of $36.8 billion. Andy Jassy has been spearheading growth and cost-cutting measures in 2023 have increased shareholder confidence. With operating income, EPS and FCF trending in the right direction, Amazon is one of the best elite growth stocks to buy in 2024. Netflix (NFLX) Source: XanderSt \/ Shutterstock.comNetflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) dominates global streaming and they are well positioned to gain market share over the next decade. Management's restructuring efforts have been working, and their new ad plan membership continues to gain traction.   Netflix's management issued optimistic guidance for FY24 after implementing broad cost-cutting measures in 2023. This resulted in the company seeing a recovery in revenue and EPS while delivering record FCF from operations. In the 2023 fiscal year, Netflix's FCF ballooned to $6.9 billion, and its operating margin expanded by 280 basis points. Their new ad plan membership has created a new revenue growth opportunity, and they continue to crack down on password sharing.  They are clearly doing something right, and there is enough evidence to believe that growth will continue. Netflix currently boasts more than 260 million global subscribers and their new ad plan membership will likely boost advertising revenue growth. The company forecasts revenue of $9.24 billion in Q1 FY24, implying approximately 13% YOY growth. Furthermore, they expect operating margins to expand by 520 basis points (bps). This makes Netflix one of the top elite growth stocks to buy right now. Spotify (SPOT) Source: Fabio Principe \/ Shutterstock.comSpotify (NYSE:SPOT) is a global music streaming giant that is set to deliver outsized returns over the next decade. They may be inches closer to achieving GAAP profitability for a full fiscal year, which could propel them to new heights.  Spotify delivered a strong operational year in 2023 despite the company remaining unprofitable. Revenue increased 13% YOY to $13.24 billion, with FCF hitting a record 674 million. However, what got investors excited was the company delivering a surprise profit of $0.33 per share in Q3 2023. They continue to see diversified growth with Latin American and the rest of the world growing at a more than 15% CAGR.  In FY23, Spotify's monthly active users (MAU) hit 602 million and the company is on pace to surpass 1 billion MAU's in the next few years. Gross margin expansions have been key to drive profitable growth and premium subscriptions are growing by double digits across all regions. Additionally, the company's liquidity remains strong with approximately $4.3 billion in cash and marketable securities. As operating losses continue to shrink over the next several quarters, Spotify remains one of the premier elite growth stocks to buy in March.   On the date of publication, Terel Miles did not have (either directly or indirectly) any positions in the securities mentioned in this article. The opinions expressed in this article are those of the writer, subject to the InvestorPlace.com Publishing Guidelines. story">							<p>Finding elite <a class="auto-linked-term" href="https://investorplace.com/stock-types/growth-stocks/">growth stocks</a> to buy to outperform the market is a worthy endeavor. These companies can be characterized by their consistent expansion of revenue, earnings and market capitalization. </p><p>Elite growth stocks go hand in hand with innovative industries like artificial intelligence. Investors who are seeking to build portfolios with a focus on long-term capital appreciation gravitate towards these stocks, recognizing their potential to outperform their competitors. If you’re patient with a long-term mindset, rest assured that you’ll be sitting comfortably with these three elite companies. </p><p>Now, let’s discuss the three best elite growth stocks to buy right now!</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Amazon (AMZN)</strong></h2><div id="1444591" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-300x169.jpg" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Amazon LOGO ON THE SIDE OF A BUILDING." class="alignright wp-image-1444591" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-300x169.jpg 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-768x432.jpg 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-1024x576.jpg 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-200x113.jpg 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-400x225.jpg 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-116x65.jpg 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-100x56.jpg 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-89x50.jpg 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10-78x44.jpg 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/amzn-stock-10.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: Sundry Photography / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Amazon </strong>(NASDAQ:<span class="stock-ticker"><a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/amzn-stock-quote/"><strong><u>AMZN</u></strong></a></span>)<strong> </strong>hit a key inflection point in 2023 making it primed for more upside. It continues to lead from the front in the artificial intelligence (<span class="ignore-ticker-auto-linking">AI</span>) revolution and is set to become the world’s largest company by revenue. </p><p>Generative AI will continue to be one of the leading investment ideas for the foreseeable future. Bloomberg Intelligence estimates the <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/company/press/generative-ai-to-become-a-1-3-trillion-market-by-2032-research-finds/" rel="nofollow">generative AI market to become a $1.3 trillion industry by 2032</a>, growing at a mindblowing 42% compounded annual growth rate (<span class="ignore-ticker-auto-linking">CAGR</span>). Amazon stands to get a big piece of the pie, through their comprehensive suite of generative AI products. This includes Amazon Bedrock, Amazon Q, Code Whisperer and AWS Tranium. </p><p>In <a href="https://ir.aboutamazon.com/news-release/news-release-details/2024/Amazon.com-Announces-Fourth-Quarter-Results/" rel="nofollow">FY23</a>, Amazon’s revenue increased 12% year-over-year (<span class="ignore-ticker-auto-linking">YOY</span>) to $574.8 billion. Operating income skyrocketed to $36.9 billion, compared with $12.2 billion in 2022. However, what got Wall Street<em> </em>excited is Amazon’s record free cash flow (<span class="ignore-ticker-auto-linking">FCF</span>) of $36.8 billion. Andy Jassy has been spearheading growth and cost-cutting measures in 2023 have increased shareholder confidence. With operating income, EPS and FCF trending in the right direction, Amazon is one of the best elite growth stocks to buy in 2024.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Netflix (NFLX)</strong></h2><div id="1446212" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-300x169.jpg" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Netflix (NFLX) app open on a phone screen" class="alignright wp-image-1446212" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-300x169.jpg 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-768x432.jpg 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-1024x576.jpg 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-200x113.jpg 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-400x225.jpg 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-116x65.jpg 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-100x56.jpg 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-89x50.jpg 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7-78x44.jpg 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/nflx-stock-1600-7.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: XanderSt / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Netflix </strong>(NASDAQ:<span class="stock-ticker"><a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/nflx-stock-quote/"><strong><u>NFLX</u></strong></a></span>)<strong> </strong>dominates global streaming and they are well positioned to gain market share over the next decade. Management’s restructuring efforts have been working, and their new ad plan membership continues to gain traction.  </p><p>Netflix’s management issued optimistic guidance for FY24 after implementing broad cost-cutting measures in 2023. This resulted in the company seeing a recovery in revenue and EPS while delivering record FCF from operations. In the <a href="https://s22.q4cdn.com/959853165/files/doc_financials/2023/q4/NEW-FINAL-Q4-23-Shareholder-Letter.pdf" rel="nofollow">2023 fiscal year</a>, Netflix’s FCF ballooned to $6.9 billion, and its operating margin expanded by 280 basis points. Their new ad plan membership has created a new revenue growth opportunity, and they continue to crack down on password sharing. </p><p>They are clearly doing something right, and there is enough evidence to believe that growth will continue. Netflix currently boasts more than 260 million global subscribers and their new ad plan membership will likely boost advertising revenue growth. The company forecasts revenue of $9.24 billion in Q1 FY24, implying approximately 13% YOY growth. Furthermore, they expect operating margins to expand by 520 basis points (bps). This makes Netflix one of the top elite growth stocks to buy right now.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Spotify (SPOT)</strong></h2><div id="2202552" class="wp-caption alignright"><img src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-300x169.png" decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="300" height="169" alt="Close up view of a smartphone with Spotify (SPOT) logo on display. Laptop and headphone on background. New technology, social media, network, liquid music concept." class="alignright wp-image-2202552" srcset="https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-300x169.png 300w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-1024x576.png 1024w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-768x432.png 768w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-1536x864.png 1536w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-200x113.png 200w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-400x225.png 400w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-116x65.png 116w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-100x56.png 100w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-89x50.png 89w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600-78x44.png 78w, https://investorplace.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/spot_spotify_1600.png 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"><div class="ipm_image_source">Source: Fabio Principe / Shutterstock.com</div></div><p><strong>Spotify </strong>(NYSE:<span class="stock-ticker"><a href="https://investorplace.com/stock-quotes/spot-stock-quote/"><u><strong>SPOT</strong></u></a></span>)<strong> </strong>is a global music streaming giant that is set to deliver outsized returns over the next decade. They may be inches closer to achieving GAAP profitability for a full fiscal year, which could propel them to new heights. </p><p>Spotify delivered a strong operational year in 2023 despite the company remaining unprofitable. Revenue increased 13% YOY to $13.24 billion, with FCF hitting a record 674 million. However, what got investors excited was the company delivering a surprise profit of $0.33 per share in <a href="https://s29.q4cdn.com/175625835/files/doc_financials/2023/q3/Shareholder-Deck-Q3-2023-FINAL.pdf" rel="nofollow">Q3 2023</a>. They continue to see diversified growth with Latin American and the rest of the world growing at a more than 15% CAGR. </p><p>In <a href="https://s29.q4cdn.com/175625835/files/doc_financials/2023/q4/Shareholder-Deck-Q4-2023-FINAL.pdf" rel="nofollow">FY23</a>, Spotify’s monthly active users (<span class="ignore-ticker-auto-linking">MAU</span>) hit 602 million and the company is on pace to surpass 1 billion MAU’s in the next few years. Gross margin expansions have been key to drive profitable growth and premium subscriptions are growing by double digits across all regions. Additionally, the company’s liquidity remains strong with approximately $4.3 billion in cash and marketable securities. As operating losses continue to shrink over the next several quarters, Spotify remains one of the premier elite growth stocks to buy in March.  </p><p><em>On the date of publication, Terel Miles did not have (either directly or indirectly) any positions in the securities mentioned in this article. Greggs reported a pretax profit of 188.3m for last year, up from 148.3m in 2022. (Aaron Chown - PA Images via Getty Images) Greggs (GRG.L) Staff at UK fast food chain Greggs are among the beneficiaries of a stellar earnings report, and are set to share a 17.6m ($22.3m) bonus later this month among 25,000 of them, as its annual profits soared 27% in 2023. The chain reported a pretax profit of 188.3m for last year, up from 148.3m in 2022. Like-for-like sales were up 13.7%. The company shares out 10% of its profits each year to staff who've been working there for at least six months. Read more: FTSE 100 LIVE: European stocks fall amid gloomy data for UK high street Shares were up 4.3% by late-morning in London. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) Bitcoin continued its rally on Tuesday, skirting all-time highs against the dollar as positive sentiment buoyed the market. Over the last 24 hours the cryptocurrency was up 3%, to trade at around $67,000. The bump has been attributed to market confidence following the approval of a spot bitcoin ETF in the US earlier this year and the upcoming halving event. Read more: Crypto live prices Halving drives miners to optimise energy consumption and increase hash power. Its meant to optimise the network for the long-term. Tesla (TSLA) Shares of Tesla (TSLA) fell on Monday and in premarket trading on Tuesday following news that the EV maker's shipments fell in February as it announced price cuts in China. The company reported 60,365 vehicle shipments from its Giga Shanghai factory in February, according to preliminary data from Chinas PCA (Passenger Car Association) via Bloomberg. The February shipments represent a 16% drop from a month ago, a 19% drop from a year ago, and the lowest shipment total since December 2022. Tesla shares closed down 7.16%, its lowest close since 13 February, and looked set to fall a further 2.2% when markets open in the US later on. Read more: Stocks that are trending today Shares of Ford (F) have risen as US sales for the company rose 10.5% year-over-year for the month of February. Apple (AAPL) Apple received its first ever fine from antitrust regulators in the EU on Monday, to the tune of 1.8bn ($2bn). The smackdown is for preventing Spotify (SPOT) and other music streamers from touting payment options outside of its app store. Story continues The decision has been in the works since 2019, when Spotify argued against Apple's 30% App Store fees and the payments restriction. "For a decade, Apple abused its dominant position in the market for the distribution of music streaming apps through the App Store," European Commission competition chief Margrethe Vestager said in a statement. Read more: The pros and cons of a 99% mortgage "They did so by restricting developers from informing consumers about alternative, cheaper music services available outside of the Apple ecosystem. This is illegal under EU antitrust rules." Stock fell 2.4% on Monday and continued its descent in premarket trading on Tuesday. Watch: Apple's China iPhone sales plunge as Huawei gains

That's according to leading research firm Counterpoint.

The U.S. company took a hit due to stronger competition from domestic Chinese competitors.

The report said Apple's main local rival Huawei saw unit sales up 64% in the period.

Apple dropped to fourth place in terms of Chinese market share.

It was second in the same period last year, when it made up almost a fifth of the market.

Huawei took that position as its market share expanded to 16.5% from just under a tenth a year earlier.

But the report showed the overall smartphone market in China shrank 7%.

Apple began subsidizing certain iPhone models in the country by as much as $180 last week.

It had already offered discounts on its official sites last month.

Huawei has seen premium smartphone sales rise since it released its Mate 60 series in August.

The firm had struggled for years with U.S. restrictions placed on it, but sales suggest it is finally seeing a way out of trouble.","thumbnailUrl":"https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/NNJB4tfgj__RsKup1Jw23A--~B/aD01NDA7dz05NjA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/video.reutersnews.com/e23470702d2abb95c3da6a0823026059","duration":"PT1M8S","contentUrl":"https://video.media.yql.yahoo.com/v1/video/sapi/hlsstreams/21c56399-0134-317d-87bf-56314fd8dc56.m3u8?site=finance®ion=GB&lang=en-GB&devtype=desktop&src=sapi","embedUrl":"https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/video/apples-china-iphone-sales-plunge-095132268.html?format=embed","identifier":"21c56399-0134-317d-87bf-56314fd8dc56"} Download the Yahoo Finance app, available for Apple and Android.

articles.title: US STOCKS-S&P 500 edges lower as investors hold their breath ahead of economic data
summarizedBulletPoints: - Apple was hit by a $2-billion EU antitrust fine for preventing Spotify (which owns the stock symbol SPOT) and other music streaming services from informing users of alternative payment options outside its App Store.
- The S&P 500 saw slightly lower closings after a day of mixed trading, influenced by investors' anticipation of economic data and Fed Chair Jerome Powell's congressional testimony.

- Despite the broader market's mixed results, rallies in chip stocks, including Nvidia, propelled the S&P 500 to fresh intraday records, driven by continued investor confidence in demand for AI technology.
- The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite experienced declines, with communications services and technology shares among the impacted sectors.
- Upcoming U.S. economic data, including service sector readings and non-farm payroll numbers, are highly anticipated by investors for insights into the health of the economy.
- Artificial intelligence-driven tech rallies continue to capture Wall Street's attention, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high at the start of March.
- Fed Chair Jerome Powell's upcoming testimony before lawmakers is eagerly awaited for its potential impact on market directions.
- Shares of AI server manufacturer Super Micro Computer and shoe maker Deckers Outdoor surged ahead of their inclusion in the S&P 500 index.
- Macy's share price jumped following an increased buyout offer from Arkhouse Management and Brigade Capital Management.
articles.desc:
*

Apple hit by EU antitrust fine in Spotify case

*

Macy's jumps after Arkhouse, Brigade raise buyout bid

*

Super Micro Computer jumps ahead of S&P 500 entry

*

Indexes down: Dow 0.25%, S&P 0.12%, Nasdaq 0.41%

(Updates with final prices after market close)

By Sinad Carew and Ankika Biswas

March 4 (Reuters) - The S&P 500 closed slightly lower on Monday after a choppy trading day as investors took a pause ahead of economic data and Fed Chair Jerome Powell's congressional testimony.

Apple closed down 2.5% following a $2-billion EU antitrust fine for preventing Spotify and other music streaming services from informing users of payment options outside its App Store.

Rallies in chip stocks, including Nvidia, helped advance the S&P 500 to fresh intraday records during the session as investors continued to bet on demand for products powering artificial intelligence (AI) even though were broadly cautious ahead of economic data.

But the S&P 500, after turning slightly positive late in the day, started to lose ground again in the last hour of trading to fall back into the red in the last few minutes of trading.

"This is one of those days where investors are on hold for the economic data that's coming out later this week," said Burns McKinney, portfolio manager, NFJ Investment Group.

Investors were waiting for insights into the U.S. economy's health from key monthly data such as readings on the service sector, due on Tuesday, and non-farm payrolls data due Friday, according to Scott Wren, senior global market strategist at Wells Fargo Investment Institute.

"The market is still trying to digest what the outlook is for the economy, earnings and the Federal Reserve," said Wren but he noted that both institutional and retail investors have some fear of missing out as they watch stocks hit fresh records.

"There's institutional money that can't sit on the books and watch the S&P 500 go higher every day and retail investors are starting to have the fear of missing out," said Wren. "Stocks are expensive but that doesn't mean they can't get more expensive before some kind of a pullback. Momentum is carrying the market and positive thinking is carrying the market."

Story continues

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 97.55 points, or 0.25%, to 38,989.83, the S&P 500 lost 6.13 points, or 0.12%, to 5,130.95 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 67.43 points, or 0.41%, to 16,207.51.

The S&P 500's communications services index was the benchmark's weakest sector, ending down 1.5%, while defensive utilities, which added 1.6%, was its biggest gainer for the day.

The Nasdaq had kicked off March by hitting an intraday record high on Friday, also closing at its highest level for two straight days, as the artificial intelligence-driven tech rally continues to steal the spotlight on Wall Street.

The S&P 500 has also been on a winning streak recently, jumping over 21% with four straight months of gains through February. BofA Global Research lifted its year-end target for the benchmark index to 5,400, from 5,000, representing a 5% upside from current levels.

Along with economic data, investors are also waiting for comments from Fed chair Powell, who is due to testify before lawmakers on Wednesday and Thursday.

AI server maker Super Micro Computer finished up 18.6% and shoe maker Deckers Outdoor rose 2.6% ahead of their inclusion in the S&P 500 index.

Shares in Macy's jumped 13.5% after real-estate-focused investing firm Arkhouse Management and Brigade Capital Management raised their offer for the department store chain.

Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.20-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.44-to-1 ratio favored decliners.

The S&P 500 posted 106 new 52-week highs and 8 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 194 new highs and 99 new lows.

On U.S. exchanges 12.69 billion shares changed hands, ahead of the 11.87 billion moving average for the last 20 sessions.

(Reporting by Sinad Carew in New York, Ankika Biswas and Amruta Khandekar in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel and Aurora Ellis)

US STOCKS-S&P 500 edges lower as investors hold their breath ahead of economic data

Sinad Carew and Ankika Biswas
March 4, 2024 at 1:23 PM·4 min read

*

Apple hit by EU antitrust fine in Spotify case

*

Macy's jumps after Arkhouse, Brigade raise buyout bid

*

Super Micro Computer jumps ahead of S&P 500 entry

*

Indexes down: Dow 0.25%, S&P 0.12%, Nasdaq 0.41%

(Updates with final prices after market close)

By Sinad Carew and Ankika Biswas

March 4 (Reuters) - The S&P 500 closed slightly lower on Monday after a choppy trading day as investors took a pause ahead of economic data and Fed Chair Jerome Powell's congressional testimony.

Apple closed down 2.5% following a $2-billion EU antitrust fine for preventing Spotify and other music streaming services from informing users of payment options outside its App Store.

Rallies in chip stocks, including Nvidia, helped advance the S&P 500 to fresh intraday records during the session as investors continued to bet on demand for products powering artificial intelligence (AI) even though were broadly cautious ahead of economic data.

But the S&P 500, after turning slightly positive late in the day, started to lose ground again in the last hour of trading to fall back into the red in the last few minutes of trading.

"This is one of those days where investors are on hold for the economic data that's coming out later this week," said Burns McKinney, portfolio manager, NFJ Investment Group.

Investors were waiting for insights into the U.S. economy's health from key monthly data such as readings on the service sector, due on Tuesday, and non-farm payrolls data due Friday, according to Scott Wren, senior global market strategist at Wells Fargo Investment Institute.

"The market is still trying to digest what the outlook is for the economy, earnings and the Federal Reserve," said Wren but he noted that both institutional and retail investors have some fear of missing out as they watch stocks hit fresh records.

"There's institutional money that can't sit on the books and watch the S&P 500 go higher every day and retail investors are starting to have the fear of missing out," said Wren. "Stocks are expensive but that doesn't mean they can't get more expensive before some kind of a pullback. Momentum is carrying the market and positive thinking is carrying the market."

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 97.55 points, or 0.25%, to 38,989.83, the S&P 500 lost 6.13 points, or 0.12%, to 5,130.95 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 67.43 points, or 0.41%, to 16,207.51.

The S&P 500's communications services index was the benchmark's weakest sector, ending down 1.5%, while defensive utilities, which added 1.6%, was its biggest gainer for the day.

The Nasdaq had kicked off March by hitting an intraday record high on Friday, also closing at its highest level for two straight days, as the artificial intelligence-driven tech rally continues to steal the spotlight on Wall Street.

The S&P 500 has also been on a winning streak recently, jumping over 21% with four straight months of gains through February. BofA Global Research lifted its year-end target for the benchmark index to 5,400, from 5,000, representing a 5% upside from current levels.

Along with economic data, investors are also waiting for comments from Fed chair Powell, who is due to testify before lawmakers on Wednesday and Thursday.

AI server maker Super Micro Computer finished up 18.6% and shoe maker Deckers Outdoor rose 2.6% ahead of their inclusion in the S&P 500 index.

Shares in Macy's jumped 13.5% after real-estate-focused investing firm Arkhouse Management and Brigade Capital Management raised their offer for the department store chain.

Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.20-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.44-to-1 ratio favored decliners.

The S&P 500 posted 106 new 52-week highs and 8 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 194 new highs and 99 new lows.

On U.S. exchanges 12.69 billion shares changed hands, ahead of the 11.87 billion moving average for the last 20 sessions.
